thread.title: More than 200 pubs have closed since 2001 - but one part of Devon is bucking the trend

author: Hannah Finch
title: More than 200 pubs have closed since 2001 - but one part of Devon is bucking the trend
text:
Regulars at The King Billy are awaiting to hear what date it will close Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
More than 200 pubs have been lost in Devon since 2001, new figures show.
New data published by the Office of National Statistics shows that the number of small village pubs have been hardest hit.
But there has been a rise in bigger pubs and the number of people employed in the trade is also up.
Plymouth has seen the biggest loss of pubs with 60 closing their doors between 2001 and 2018.
Yet the number of pubs in the South Hams has stayed the same. Pub closures in Devon from 2001-2018 ONS
People drinking at home, the smoking ban and the high costs of keeping the doors open have been blamed for the closures. Read More Wetherspoons' boss Tim Martin on his favourite Exeter pubs, the best â€˜spoons, students, Brexit and pink gin
In Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly, the number of pubs has dropped from 580 in 2001 to 555 in 2018.
The Isles of Scilly has seen a rise in number from five to 10, according to the data.
Across the UK, the number of pubs has shrunk from around 52,500 in 2001 to 38,815 in 2018. However, overall turnover has largely held up, falling by 8%, taking account of inflation, while the numbers employed have actually increased 6%. Ten Devon pubs we have loved and lost
